geeklist.title: 10 Tips for Gaming with a Brain Injury
geeklist.description: I served in the United States Army as a 19D Cavalry Scout, with one deployment to Iraq in 2007. On February 23rd of 2007, I was struck by a pressure plate IED while approaching our Observation Post outside of Ramadi, "OP Shadow", the resulting explosion broke my leg, cut me with shrapnel, and gave me a Traumatic Brain Injury. I lost about 50-60% of my ability to recall, and my memory is pretty shot, especially short term memory. This caused me to have to learn new ways to live life, and perhaps more importantly, new ways to be good at board games. I would love to share some of the gaming tips I have learned that help me play games with a brain injury. I hope you enjoy my list and the things I have learned from my experience.

item.body: Listen, you have got to accept it, your noggin don't work the same as it used to. Your gonna forget rules, what games you've played, what you did on previous turns; hell, your gonna forget if you even liked the games sometimes. Use BGG to help supplement your memory. Rank games right after playing, add notes to remember specific things and thoughts, and keep your collection up to date! It only takes a couple of games not added to easily forget you even have a game.

Strategy is not your friend, especially in long games. Sure, you can start a game with an idea of what you want to do, but it will be gone from your head quicker than that one very important thing your spouse told you they really need from the store. Let it go, and lean as hard as you can into our next list item!

If strategy is your enemy, then being tactical is your best friend. The definition that applies best here comes from Merriam-Webster: (1) : of or relating to small-scale actions serving a larger purpose. (2) : made or carried out with only a limited or immediate end in view.
Your brain thrives on tactical decisions, use that! You already forgot your main strategy, so now you are left with different, shorter strategies, like "get points" or "make Bradley pay for that hyper-aggressive turn one move that you did nothing to deserve". Just focus on your next turn, no point thinking too far ahead, you will just forget your plan anyway.

There is a special feeling you get when you play a game the very first time. All the systems to explore, the fun, deciding if you like or love the game, it's really great! Well good news my friend, you have a super power which let's you experience that with the same game multiple times, at least until you have played it enough times that it makes it into your long-term memory. Play a game, wait a month, put it back on the table, those poor suckers at the table may remember and prefer to play something new, but it is new to you again, so they can live with it!

Listen, you have got to accept it, your noggin don't work the same as it used to. Your gonna forget rules, what games you've played, what you did on previous turns; hell, your gonna forget if you even liked the games sometimes. Use BGG to help supplement your memory. Rank games right after playing, add notes to remember specific things and thoughts, and keep your collection up to date! It only takes a couple of games not added to easily forget you even have a game.

Ahh, good old Anomia, the struggle to remember or find a word or name of a thing. This is an all-day, everyday occurrence, and it will happen in gaming often. You will forget the name of a game, designer, mechanic, etc. When you find your brain cloud is completely overcast, feel free to just make up a word, or even better, just point and grunt. Gamers are friendly people who will generally just smile and nod when you say something dumb, plus, it may just fly if you say it (or grunt it) confidently enough.

item.objectname: Forgotten Waters: Card and Counter Organizer
item.body: Many times I have finished my turn, had a plan for the next one, and forgotten by the time it gets back to my turn. Perhaps your good friend knows you forget stuff, and uses this to his advantage by taking some extra time on his turn, "Rob forgets easily, so if I milk this turn, he is sure to lose". Haha, there is a trick for this, so you are hoisted by your own petard my friend. The trick? While it is still in your head, organize your cards and pieces to remind you of what you wanted to play/use, that way you create a system which will guide your tactical decision in the next round!

What about games in your own collection and rules you need to teach? My tip from experience, your never going to remember games that have too many rules, edge cases, and rules grit. You have to accept that you may not be the best steward for a game. Hegemony was a recent example, I got the game, taught it, then realized I should not be the champion for that game. Every time I taught the game I would have to completely relearn the rules, and relearn the teach. That's just not sustainable. So I pawned it off to a friend for him to be the teacher/champion. If I want to play, he would be happy to GM the game, so that's a win. Mid to low weight games are your gravy baby!

Clearly, due to your dumb brain, winning a bunch of games will not be your thing. There will obviously be some lucky days, but overall, you are not gonna be the champ often. Lean into the friendship and fun with friends and family! It makes every gameday awesome, not matter what game gets tabled! For those playing with the people this list is about, there is something important to know: They say you never get a second chance to make a first impression, but when playing with a person with a brain injury, you definitely do! Have fun, and if you really want to have fun with your new forgetful friend, pick a new name for yourself every time you meet them, you will blow their mind!
